TopicTitle: Most important lesson you've learned in KSP?

Articles.Content: Never map a booster activation to the same command as a decoupling. The lower stages will explode. A lot.

Why are you dumping a lit booster?
Strut your pancake tanks together, else they'll wobble your ship clean apart.

Failure to reinforce your parachutes (and/or whatever they're directly attached to) with struts can result in them ripping clean off when they open.

This tends to be bad for the rest of the craft.

It feels like cheating, but...briefly turning time warp on and off again will immediately stop your craft from rotating. This makes it easy (even for large, sluggish craft) to hit the target on your navball without overshooting it and without having to slow your rotation before you get to the target.

Here's one I remembered. Delta V is important. So is Thrust-to-Weight ratio.

All the Delta V in the world won't help if you can't get off the ground...

The most important thing I learned is this:

Assign a Job (or jobs) to each stage.

If the stage is not able to complete it's assigned jobs - go back and rework the stage.

Don't let later stages cover for the failures of early stages; it will just lead to you running out of propellant for your mission.

The most complex design is not always the best when trying to get to a distant location. Sometimes, a smaller, stripped-down, more efficient version can get you there without the headache of making sure all the staging is correct!

Something I learned that is terribly important: When creating an ejection system, remember to use a decoupler. While the two sepratrons and radial 'chute will remove the front of the ship at ~175m/s, they won't remain long enough to keep the pilot alive.
Always always ALWAYS put the RCS blocks DIRECTLY ontop of the center of mass. Four blocks at the front and four at the back WILL NOT HELP YOU DOCK.
Attempting to land in a field with a jet powered by 3 turbojets while descending at roughly 10m/s does not end well for anything except the center 2/3rds of the fuselage.
